questions.question: What are the 3 parts of the Inverted Pyramid?

choices.answer: Who, What, When, Where, Why & How

questions.question: The majority of news stories should be composed of which part of the inverted pyramid?

choices.answer: The most important details (The Who, What, When, Where, Why and How)

questions.question: . What are the 5 W’s & the H? (Select all that apply)

choices.answer: Who, What, When, Where, Why & How
Who, What, Where, Welcome, Why, How
Who, Woman, Water, Wine, Witch, How
The most important details of the news story

questions.question: Which Statement represents the Who, What, When, Where, Why and How of a proper news story?

choices.answer: Yesterday, a plane crash killed 4 people
In December the Farmer moved his pigs to the barn located in Orlando, FL.

questions.question: What is the basis for worthiness of a news story? (The most IMPORTANT thing)
True or False: The First Amendment gives all Journalists compete freedom when reporting the news
The quality of being trusted and believed in is referred to as...?
The quality of being honest and having strong moral principles is referred to as...?
A person who is able to be relied on as honest and truthful is said to have...?
A news sources coming from an unknown author or one who is not named or identified is referred to a what?
A news sources that comes from a private or secret source is referred to as what?
Plagiarism means to: (Select 3 of the following which represent Plagiarism.)

choices.answer: Directly stating the source of the information in a news report
Passing off someone else’s work as your own
Presenting a “New and Original” idea which was taken from an existing sourc
Using information without crediting the source

questions.question: Select all of the scenarios below that would be considered plagiarism

choices.answer: Copying so many words/ideas from a sources that it makes up the majority of
Copying words from someone else without giving credit
Having your friend share their GoogleDoc with you and turning it in as your
Not citing information that is considered Common Knowledge

questions.question: Using quotations and directly stating where you found your information are techniques used to avoid plagiarism
Which of the following is true of information that is considered "Common Knowledge" (Select all that apply)

choices.answer: Common Knowledge does not have to be cited
The information could easily find in general reference sources
The information you’re presenting is something readers will already know
The same info can be found undocumented in at least 5 other credible source

questions.question: These must be identical and only use a small section of the original source
This is a way of restating the main idea in your own words
Which of the following is an example of Plagiarism?

choices.answer: Accidently misstating facts from your source during your news report
A journalism student submits a published magazine article for his own woek
Using quotations makes and citing your source in your article
Writing your news report using your own words

questions.question: Damage to a person/organization’s reputation/standing in the community or exposing a person/organization to public shame
Damage to a person’s reputation caused by a false written statement that brings the person into hatred, contempt...
Which of the following is an example of Libel?

choices.answer: Journalist writing  retraction after they discover they used incorrect fcts
Purposefully misrepresenting facts from your source during a news report
Reporter writes false story claiming that a landlord refuses to clean mold
Writing a news report using credible sources

questions.question: "spoken defamation" words which tend to expose one to public hatred, shame, contempt, ridicule, aversion, or disgrace
What is the major difference between "libel" and "slander"?
The right of authors to control the reproduction and use of their creative expressions is referred to as...?
This doctrine allows limited copying of copyrighted works for educational & research purposes
If you find something on the internet it is in the public domain and therefore copyright law does not apply?
Knowledge, creative ideas or expression of human mind that have commercial value and are protectable under copyright, TM
What concepts are covered by Intellectual property laws?

choices.answer: The idea or the work itself
The invention created from the idea
The relationship between a symbol and a business

questions.question: Who owns it: You are working for a company and as part of your assigned task you create something while “On-Duty”
You are working for a company, while “Off-duty” you create something new and original that is not related to your job
You work for a company & signed an Intellectual Property clause. You create something while "off-duty" unrelated to work
A journalist claims they have the legal rights to the manuscript they personally wrote. What is the manuscript an EX of?
Reporter writing story on law to ban pits. Interviewed local citizens who agree & Pet owners who don't. Ethical mistake?

choices.answer: The reporter did not interview the right people
The reporter submitted the article late
The story presented one side of an issue

questions.question: Editor for local paper has a dispute with a reporter. For months falsely claims he did not get the report & runs own
Copyright law states that reproduction for certain purposes is not an infringement of copyright. What are those purposes
